reviews.review_title: The BRATZ are not THE BRATZ.
reviews.content: When I saw its trailer, I got really excited because for one, it was really cool that they're going to do a real life version of Bratz. And yes I love Bratz the cartoon one of course. But when I saw it *gasp* it was just a good thing that I watched it at home. Pros:1. The movie was very colorful, which is a big deal for visual people. 2. And there's the good sense of fashion, present in the movie.Cons:1. The story was very Cliché. The plot was not planned out. I bet that the film was rushed, i mean come on cliques that don't click? It was like a mix of Van Wilder 2 and other movies that had clique in them.2. The movie was so CORNY. That part after they had the food fight scene, where Jasmine said, "Stop it!" And they ended up a friends? Was so Uggh! It made me want to gag!!!3. The actresses' acting, or rather everybody's ACTING was WAY OVER THE TOP. 4. The part were Dylan portrayed that he was deaf. He really didn't portray it. I know that he can lip read but, the way that he did it, he can get what the others are saying like *snap of fingers* that!5. Jasmine's voice was so not good. It's too nasal-y. Meredith's voice was way better than hers. Why the heck was it that the lead in this movie is Jasmine? When the lead is always Chloe. Is there some reason behind this? And Oh yeah! What the heck was that part, where Dylan had his own scene? Where the music teacher helped him and everything? It reminded me of Drumline, you know the movie.

reviews.review_title: why do peaple think that this is a bad moveie?
reviews.content: I thongh that this was a good moveies.kidhood marorres.

reviews.review_title: I lost the will to live.
reviews.content: So we decided to watch this film, as a laugh. It was Very far from a laugh, it was terrifying and traumatising, The shrieking awful actresses with their squeaky voices running amok screaming 'BFF' and 'IT'S ALL ABOUT ME' sent traumatic shudders up my spine. This piece of tripe is not a CHICK FLICK, nor is it a kids film, it's a horror movie, that resides in your brain and destroys it after watching it. I can honestly say that, my brain is still in the process of recovering.The deaf boy wasn't really deaf, I don't think i reluctant deaf boy would have learnt to lip read in such a quick time, nor speak properly. Furthermore, the final performance 'bratitude' is the WORST WORST WORST performance ever. No she cannot sing, and they cannot dance. =_=.

reviews.review_title: I don't know what I expected
reviews.content:
First of all, after reading some previous comments... I watched this movie on purpose. I played with bratz dolls when I was young and even had a few computer games, one of which was based on this movie. 
I have long growned out of the designated audience age but when I saw the movie on netflix I thought I give it a try.I was surprised to see some quite good actors in a seemingly horrible early performence. I give this movie a 1 star rating because it has no substence I could not enjoy it.However, consider that this movie is quite old and aimed at children, there was nothing else to expect. The actors where not given a solid script or plot to work out there full potential. They need to overreact and stay simple without any layers. 
This movie is supposed to be like this, for kids. A 1 rating for me as an adult. But if I would have seen the movie when I first longed for it (age 10 or something) I may not love it but probably enjoyed my time anyway.Soundtrack by the way... for this kind of movie surprisingly great!

reviews.review_title: Loved it!!
reviews.content: I absolutely adored this film! The values that are present throughout this entire masterpiece allows my faith to be returned in all of film making. Christopher Nolan, Steven Spielberg, Martin Scorsese and every producer/director out there should take a leaf out of this film's book as it is and absolute classic. My all-time favourite movie of all time!Apparently there needs to be at least 10 lines for it to pass as a review, so please enjoy these instructions for making brownies; Method Step 1 Preheat oven to 160C/140C fan-forced. Grease a 6cm-deep, 22cm square cake pan. Line base and sides with baking paper, extending paper 2cm above edges of pan. Step 2 Place chocolate and butter in a medium saucepan over low heat. Cook, stirring, for 5 minutes or until melted and smooth. Cool for 5 minutes. Step 3 Add sugar and egg, whisking to combine. Stir in flour and cocoa until combined. Add choc bits and sour cream. Stir to combine. Spread chocolate mixture into prepared pan. Dollop with caramel. Using a butter knife, swirl mixture to create a marbled effect. Step 4 Bake for 1 hour or until a skewer inserted into the centre of brownie comes out with moist crumbs clinging. Cool completely in pan. Serve cut into squares.

reviews.review_title: Hating on the actors is uncalled for
reviews.content: It is not the actor's fault they were given a bad script. Many of them have gone on to do really good work. The most notable is jade, who went on to be Mona in pretty little liars, a part she played spectacularly, she was able to capture psychopath so well. And Sasha's actor went on to be one of the leads in the Netflix original dear white people, another great show. Blaming the actors for something they had no control over is extremely unfair, it's not their fault, and unless you've been in acting you don't really know how much of a struggle it can be to get parts, so blaming them for being a part of this movie is really uncalled for. Of course this is no excuse for the script, which is littered with plot holes, but it's not really a movie made for adults, it's just supposed to be entertaining for young children, and when I first saw this as a nine year old, I loved it, and rewatching it as an adult is really nostalgic for me, because I loved the franchise as a child. This doesn't mean it's a great movie by any means, and being content for children isn't an excuse to phone it in on a script, but this is no where near the worst movie I've seen, and anyone who thinks that has obviously never had the displeasure of watching movies like birdemic and food fight. There's too much hate in these reviews for the wrong thing, because the actors aren't the ones who write the script, and it's ignorant to blame them, but who could expect anything else from people in 2007.

reviews.review_title: BEST CHILDHOOD MOVIE
reviews.content: Yes, it has many plotholes, weird dialogues and other stuff, BUT IT IS ICONIC. Just don't take it too seriously! It's super fun, easy to watch and has many GIRLBOSS moments, slay.

reviews.review_title: It's been done so much better
reviews.content: Bratz: The Movie follows the lives of four total BFF high school students, Yasmin, Sasha, Chloe, and Jade, as they share their adventures through school. When they first begin their experience as freshmen, they vow to say together forever no matter what. However, their plan is road blocked when, Meridith, the creepy, stalker, spoiled queen of the school splits them up into different cliques. However, the four "Bratz" find their friendship (and fashion!) are the true important things in life and therefore decide to stop the evil Meridith's dastardly scheme together.So, normally I would probably never watch a cheap, superficial movie based on a line of anatomical incorrect dolls, but, since the particular child that I was babysitting a few weeks ago loves the movie, I pretty much had to. And now I'm still trying to wash the nasty taste out of my mouth.Really, I don't know if there are any other ways for me to describe this god awful train wreck besides what everyone else has said. And yes it is truly as bad as everyone says. But I feel it is my right to bitch after watching it, so here we go. First off, the acting is terrible. I can't think of one person's performance that wasn't amateurish, stereotypical, stupid, or all three. Even Jon Voight was awful (someone had some bills to pay?). All the characters are one dimensional. Meridith, played by an Ashley Tisdale wannabe, has such a paper thin personality, the wind could split her in half. She does not embody the evil queen bee. Instead, she's just an annoying bitch whose main past time is stalking the four "totally awesome and cool" Bratz. And the Bratz are really no better themselves. In fact, from my high school experience, those girls would probably be the annoying girls who stay in their own little clique and ignore everyone else. The plot is typical "high school" movie crap, including a party that goes terribly wrong and ending with a talent show that saves the day, giving the Bratz everything they ever need, and making sure that Meridith gets royally screwed. This movie also tires to give heartwarming "messages." What they are, I really don't know. Somehow they try to pass off something about individuality and friendship, but it comes out as muddled B.S. So, according to Bratz, the only way to be successful in life is by continually clinging to the people you've known before we came out of your mother and making sure that you always, ALWAYS, wear what's fashionable, otherwise you're a totalloser.Even though this IS based on a line of dolls, it could have been good. It could have been a satire about four fashion loving girls being almost outsiders in the normalcy of high school. It could have shown how people who are friends grow apart as they grow up (but that might also include showing ACTUAL individualism and something that could happen in the real world rather that a bunch of annoying, clingy girls who would die without each other). But, of course, it only lives of to the expectations of this type of movie: it's going to be crap. Wanna see a movie about being fashionable yet an outsider? Watch Legally Blonde. Want a satirical (and funny) look at cliques? See Mean Girls or better yet, Heathers. Because, why not watch the original movies Bratz enjoys ripping off?

reviews.review_title: Underrated AF
reviews.content: This movie slayz! Everyone freaking hates this movie but I love it so much! Plus, it's WAYYY better than the cartoonz(*shudders*)anyways, Yasmin Jade Sasha and Chloe enter high school. Yasmin tries to become a singer but chickens out, Jade becomes a scientist, Sasha becomes a cheerleader, and Chloe becomes star of the soccer team. Jade, Sasha, and Chloe's cliques scatter the Bratz and Yasmin's left alone. 2 years later, the main antagonist Meredith sabotages Chloe with her dog, who goes flying towards Sasha, who knocks into Jade, who rolls in the garbage can and flings her food at Yasmin. The girls have a food fight and are sent to detention, where they have a decent convo for the 1st time in 2 years. Later, they go to Meredith's 2nd Sweet 16 where she performs "Fabulous" and humiliates Yasmin, but Meredith gets pushed into her swimming pool by an elephant. Meredith joins the talent show, and to take her down the 4 main characters form Bratz-their girl group. Meredith performs "It's All About Me" and exposes the Bratz's secrets, but the Bratz stand up to her and perform "Bratitude". The talent show ends in a tie. Meredith wins the trophy, but the Bratz win the scholarship, which is given to Chloe, who ironically was the main character in the cartoon films. MTV then signs Bratz and they perform "Open Eyes" on the red carpet while Meredith and her dad spy on them. It's a great film! The Bratz's songs suck, but the other songs either also suck or rock! The best songs are "Take It To The Maximum" which is Sasha's cheerleading tryouts song and Meredith's songs "It's All About Me" and "Fabulous". Great movie, but if you're really criticed with movie reviews I wouldn't reccomend it.

reviews.review_title: Amazing
reviews.content: This movie is actually very interesting and enjoyable. I don't understand why people are judging it. It is one of the best comedy movie for teens I have ever seen.

reviews.review_title: Nice For Summer Girl Power
reviews.content: Well, I Watched The Movie With My Girlfriend And She Took Her Little Sister Too. For The First Five Minutes, I Thought The Movie Was So-So, But I Was Wrong, Bratz Helped My Eyes To See How Important Friendship Is. Okey, So There Are 4 BFF's Who Trying To Fit In At The New High School But They Were Failed Because A Student Evil Body President Who Splited Them Up Into Different Cliques. But With Passion For Fashion And Spirit Of Friendship, They Were Back Together And Became The BRATZ For The School Talent Show. Story Was Not Kind Of Lame Or Bad, It Was Great, Actually. Maybe For You People Who Hating The Movie Thhought That I'm Stupid Or Something, But It's True, Bratz Wasn't That Bad. Believe In Me! I'm A Guy, But I Had Enough Brave To Admit That. My Girlfriend And Her Sister Instantly Loved The Movie, They Said Bratz Was A Rare Movie About Be True To Yourself, Yup, Just Be Yourself And Love Your Family & Your Friends. The Pretty Amazing Acting Was Shown By Chelsea Staub Who Play Character Meredith. Despite She's Beautiful Actress, She Had A Very Talented Acting For Evil And Smart, Meredith. And Then Perhaps For The Bratz, Janel Parrish Who Play Jade Had The Most Nicest Acting Than The Others. But For The Characters, I Love Cloe's Character To Death! She's So Nice, Shy, And Didn't Talk Much. Goddaughter Of Jon Voight, Skyler Shaye Who Play Cloe Shown A Natural And Cute Acting. I'm Kinda Love Her... As An New Idol. Jon Voight Who Played The Principal In School Was Shown Some Funny Acting Too. Pretty Good, Actually. Plus, The Music In The Movie Was Really Cool! You Gotta Buy The Soundtrack!So, I Just Wanna Saying That, Bratz Wasn't All That Bad Of Movie, It's Not Lower Than Other Summer Girl Power, But Anyways, Bratz Was Fun And Very Lighted-Heart Movie Of Summer.

reviews.review_title: Friendship Never Diez
reviews.content: On Summer 2007, there are a lot of good movies that actually so-so for me. but this summer, there is one movie that amazed me! One truly good movie for any ages.. what movie???? Surprisingly Bratz Did It! I was afraid that the movie will be bad like everyone else said, but when I went to see It, I was Wrong, And I think everyone else were too. Bratz has good storyline about friendship, family and some passion for fashion (for the girls). just like every teen movie, lighted-heart scenes, Friendship is going to win and happy ending. but Bratz has more than that. i was confused that most of critics for the movie were bad. i didn't get it! why people so hating the movie? but anyways, for all of you who give 7 - 10 for the Bratz ratings, blessed u! and for you who give 1 - 5 for the ratings, just go to your parents and saying 'mom,dad, am i a terrible person who doesn't understand what the most important thing of friendship?'.

reviews.review_title: Who doesn't love The Bratz
reviews.content: This was one of my favorite movies as a kid. As a theater major I do feel like some of the acting could've been better but again it's a kids movie and I still to do this day enjoy watching it. Bratz over Barbie!

reviews.review_title: BFF's and OMG were worth to seeing. i'm BRATZ Lover!
reviews.content: i watched the movie over and over, again and again.. with my girl friends, guy friends, family n my self. i just want 2 say that the movie was good n as the matter of fact, it was great. it has good messages (of course), nice story, pretty acting, and awesome musics. the ending was actually a bit heart-touching when Cloe was given the present by Yasmin, jade n Sasha then she said "For Real? Oh, I Love You Guys! We're Truly Best Friends Forever" And Then They All Shouted "BFF! Even Better.. BRATZ!" well, i think yeah Bratz deserves to get 10 for the ratings. but i DON'T think that Bratz deserves to get 1 for the ratings. so, i think u have to watch it. but if u will be afraid to feel ashame for watch it in theater because u stupid, then just watch the movie on DVD. and prepare to be amazes!

reviews.review_title: You've GOTTA be kidding me!
reviews.content: I didn't lose 10 IQ points; I lost 100 IQ points! In simple words, this is the story: Cloe, Yasmin, Sasha and Jade, the 4 biggest losers ever, are starting 9th grade, where Yasmin falls in love with Dylan , Cloe falls in loves with the soccer girl & Cameron, Jade falls in love with Dexter the Dork, & Sasha falls in love with Beth! Then they become a 4 way again for a few months. Then Yasmin gets together with Merideth, and at the end, it's a group! Woo-hoo! It wouldn't even win an Oscar if it were the only movie ever! So my advice: Either don't watch it or cover your eyes & wear earplugs when you do! And if you've seen it without the requirements or you will, you suck!

reviews.review_title: My soul died
reviews.content: This movie is insulting to anyone with an IQ that isn't low enough to trip over. The racial stereotypes were abundant with this one, including a mariachi band in the kitchen of a Mexican, a dumb blonde, and a smart Asian. The plot is 4 vapid teenagers struggling with materialism and narcissism in high school. Oh, did I mention that it includes a deaf boy who can somehow hear his crush singing? Yay for continuity! If you can get past the fact that the movie is completely predictable, it is for 2 year olds after all, you might find yourself able to enjoy the stupidity of the film. Adults will definitely enjoy the predatory 16 year old boy that seems to make advances on an 11 year old every chance he gets. Acting this bad is worthy of prison time for the mental deterioration it causes all its viewers. Unless you want your child to be mentally and emotionally stunted, I would keep them as far away from this film as possible. This film will kill your soul and your brain cells.

reviews.review_title: Not bad but not good
reviews.content: I used to love this movie when I was younger but now that I've watched it again after a long time it's not as good especially since whoever sang for Yasmin doesn't even sound good nor does the voice go with her face, also who sings for her anyways?

reviews.review_title: A Cute Movie, and don't miss the video at the end.
reviews.content: I think that the movie was very cute. I don't know much about the dolls, but the movie is very lighthearted sends a good message about friendship. The girls all had their quirks without upstaging each other, and I think the actors portrayed the characters very well. My favorite was Jade, because her character seemed the most genuine and had the greatest depth. My absolute favorite part was the video that played at the end of the credits. Janel Parrish (Jade) performed a beautiful song called Rainy Day, which she wrote herself. It is on the soundtrack, which I plan to download from I-Tunes. I really hope to see a sequel.

reviews.review_title: Best movie i have ever watched
reviews.content: The Bratz 2017 movie is the best movie i have ever and will ever have watched. The bratz 2017 movie birthed me, raised me, drove me to school, paid for my school trips, put my artwork on the fridge, bought me an iphone, picked me up from parties, paid for my driving lessons, sent me to college, watched me graduate, helped me move out, loved me. I will be showing this movie to my future kids who will be showing it to my future grandkids. My dream is for a Bratz movie 2 to be made and for all of the Bratz to be in a polyamorous lesbian relationship in it. Thank you for listening.

reviews.review_title: This movie was a huge waste of time!
reviews.content: I watched this movie when I was really bored, with the hopes of it being a feel-good movie. The trailer looked decent enough, and I had expected it to be on the same level as Mean Girls.But boy was I wrong. From the first 5 minutes of the movie I wanted to tear my eyes out from the extreme fakeness of it all. They way they talk and the things they say were so horribly clichéd and they made it sound so scripted too. And more and more clichés were to come: such as the ever popular rich blonde girl with the tiny dog with her two dumb entourage.The worst part was the talent show. I think I died during that scene and then woke up again when it ended. Somehow I wanted to block it all out in fear of it destroying my brain cells.So to sum it up, do not watch Bratz if you have the tiniest bit of self dignity because at the end of the movie, you'd be punching yourself and asking "Why did I waste 2 hours of my time on this?" Oh and seriously, letting little kids watch this will not change the way they think about 'life' or 'friendship'. I cannot give them credit for deepness.

reviews.review_title: Wow
reviews.content: Much good, very like, much recommend. Good story line.

reviews.review_title: awful and probably the worst movie ever
reviews.content: This movie was probably the worst I have ever seen. It doesn't help it that it makes high school seem like a horrible place full of cliques and a mean, prissy, "boss" figure that runs the whole school. It also makes the it seem a bit to nice and immature. Honestly I don't see to many sophomores, or any year student, screaming OMG!! NO WAY!!in the halls every day. Also the whole "stupid cheer leader" thing isn't exactly realistic in high school, maybe try a few swears and they'd be heading down the right path in a typical high school. If you honestly want to see this just telling you that the obvious lip syncing done by the actress that plays Yasmin is really the cherry on top of a horrible movie. Don't forget the racial stereotypes.My final comment is don't watch it unless you want a good laugh at how stupid something is.

reviews.review_title: stupidest teen movie ever made by man kind
reviews.content: i would give zero out of ten stars if the pull-down list had that option and, sadly, it didn't i figured this would be a kid/teen movie but turned out this was just another film that lows audience IQ and morale by at least 10%.just like other typical teen movies about high schools, girl cliques have never ceased to be a prob. high schools nowadays are portrayed as social battlefields and students within are classified into categories. relationships between two sexes are no long opaque as it is clear that boy/girlfriends have become mere social endorsements. public humiliations are justified as social revenge. i wont argue much on those as they are pretty much the reality.HOWEVER, is this what adults are teaching to children, pre-teens, and teens all alike??? there are little girls, fans of bratz dolls, wanting to see this movie, and what will they take from this?? parents, keep your precious away from this movie

reviews.review_title: My eyes! They burn so bad!
reviews.content: Who would want to see these 4 girls act together in this movie? I'm glad they won those categories at the Razzies! Seriously, Yasmin can do better acting than that! The plot was awful, the actors were awful, and I caught more than 20 goofs, no lie! What's so important about this movie, anyway? The basic summary is about 4 female losers who get caught up with other losers for 730 days! Then they get in a food fight and become friends again and they try get rid of the dumb blonde! Then the Mexican becomes a moron and neglects her friends, and then everyone's happy at the end! What a good movie! It should have won an Oscar (like that would happen if it were the only movie ever)! The only thing I liked about this movie was the song "Out from Under" sung by whats-her-name. So I give this movie a 1, though it should get a 0!

reviews.review_title: it was good...if you were deaf, blind, and mute
reviews.content: OK so i was home sick the other day and i was going through my movie channels and came upon this trainwreck of a movie and thought i might as well watch it cuz there was nothing else on. worst idea ever. i only saw the second half of it and i couldn't stop twitching from all the bright colors and obnoxious Paris hilton-esquire music. i mean this is a movie about 4 girls (who suck at acting and should be banned from Hollywood) who obsess over looks, looks, and oh yeah...looks. then there is that popular girl who catagorizes the whole school into groups and everyone puts up with it. i mean what high school is this? academy of the perpetual barbies with no life? and don't even get me started on the deaf guy. at first i didn't even know he was deaf cuz he seemed to understand everyone. ughh! the only part i liked was the credits and even then you have one of them playing a piano and belting out some retarded song that had no relationship with the movie. so basically its a movie that screams "IF YOUR NOT POPULAR, PRETTY, AND HAVE A PERFECT BODY YOU WILL FAIL AT LIFE" filled with overacting, ear-bleeding songs, and outfits only prostitutes and strippers would wear.

reviews.review_title: This is the best movie ever!
reviews.content: I just saw Bratz in the theater today.First of all, the plot was just incredible. I mean, this film is truly about girl power. Gripping stuff. The companionship and bonds that these fine ladies form over the course of Bratz brings a tear to my eye.The acting in this movie is beyond average - this is Oscar winning stuff right here. I think it was adorable how the girls interacted with each other, solving problems, and coming together as a team.The plot is basically as follows: Sasha, Yasmin, Jade and Chloe enter high school. However, the beauty queen of the school, Meredith, has taken over the school, and split everybody up! Cliques have been formed, and nobody wants to hang out with each other! Needless to say, this is a very sad moment :(Obviously, this kind of behavior cannot be tolerated. By the end these wonderful girls take down Meredith, and save the school from tyranny, in a heartwarming tale of friendship and bonding over common interests. This interest being, particularly, fashion, which is a fine interest indeed. No neckbeards allowed here!I'd definitely have to recommend this movie to fans of comedy and the action genre. This movie is overflowing with comedy, and as the gals try and take down Meredith, the action just flows through smoother than food down an obese individual's mouth.

reviews.review_title: Why on earth did I used to like this?
reviews.content:
Back in the day I used to love this film. I would watch it nearly every day. Now I wonder why.I rewatched last week and it truly is terrible. The dialogue is poorly written and although the actors are trying, they aren't very good, although it's not really their fault. I feel they would've been better if the writing wasn't so ridiculous.
Also the jokes in this film aren't even funny. This film is aimed at young girls, and even in my past days of absolutely loving this film, I didn't get a lot of the jokes and just pretended to laugh at them to seem cool to my friends who were watching it with me.
Bratz tries too hard to be a more kid-friendly version of Mean Girls and other high school films. I'm rating it two stars instead of one just because of how much I loved it when I was younger. God I was an absolute idiot.

reviews.review_title: Great For Young Teens
reviews.content: Look, obviously this movie isn't the "best" of all the movies that are available in the world. However, to a young teenager, they would have a very different perspective towards it. I'm a guy and currently in college right now. I first saw this movie as a class (we voted for a movie on the last day of sixth grade in 2008 and Bratz won, so we saw it) back in elementary school and I must admit that I enjoyed it very much. True, many may question the movie's message, but in many ways I see that it does project a positive message. Throughout the movie, the four Bratz girls (Chloe, Jade, Sasha, and Yasmin) meet events that challenge their friendship. However, they make it through putting their friendship as a priority. This delivers a very important message to young teenagers/tweens that they should always learn to maintain friendships and set how to aside their differences.Another important message the movie delivers is basically how to stand up for yourself. It's very important that children in their pre- teens know this as it is very possible that they will also face similar issues once they head into highschool.Lastly, this movie wasn't intended for adults or the "general audience". It was directed towards preteens/young teens in general. Many teenagers at that time (myself included) were very interested on "what high school is going to be like". Therefore to them, this movie would be very enjoyable.

reviews.review_title: Amazing!!!!!
reviews.content: I watched this movie at the theater and OMG this is like totally amazing. The acting is beyond amazing. I just loves it it is so cute. Those girls are so tight. And to all you fat nerds who hate on us skinny models stop tripping OK cause we are gorgeous and y'all ain't/ HMM!!! This movie was so cool and amazing and I recommend to everyone even old people! Yes EVEN OLD PEOPLE! Loves It!!! Now go out and see it. These girls spill their hearts out on screen and it is just so Godly. It is the perfect movie for all of you who want to see it after you go to the mall and shop for cute outfits.P.S. To the guy who said charity and helping people is More important than fashion is obviously on something cause it ain't.

reviews.review_title: Ugly, materialistic, stupid, shallow. Exceeded expectations.
reviews.content: Honestly, I thought this movie would be worse than it was. And it was TERRIBLE. But better than I thought. I honestly felt bad for the people who put so little money into this movie (which should have been made for TV, the plot was so small and not universal). It sent messages about both how you should be yourself and how you should be cool. My ears weren't burning, my eyes weren't falling out, but I didn't want to stay in the theater. Honestly, it's a toy I played with when I was little. You can't make a movie out of it. But they did a surprisingly crappy-but-not-sickening job. Yeah, the sets were cheap and stupid, the actresses were practically B-lists, and typically, played characters with as empty and ditzy expressions as their own, but it could have been worse. But I'd prefer you don't buy this movie. And that they never wasted it and ruined the careers of some of the people who worked on it.

reviews.review_title: This movie is too much.
reviews.content: I was kind of forced to watch this when my girlfriend played it on our TV and I must say, I'm kind of angry at this movie. Just like all the other high-school movies, this movie is crammed with clichés to the teeth. There's the typical overwhelmingly snobby girl villain who suffers from severe narcissistic personality disorder who rules the school, implementing a segregating social caste system within it. The unrealistically active and thriving high school with people partying all over campus as if class never starts for them, and kids who care if four girls are sitting together at a table. All of these movies always depict this type of high school activity, yet I've never been to school where one beautiful girl calls the shots for the entire school. The cliché of the popular girl trying to bring down the main character because she shows a sign of not giving a damn who she is. The glorification of being materialistic is too much, as this seems to be a trait of every female in the movie. None of these girls are really separable in terms of personality besides the "villain".

reviews.review_title: Don't take all these over the top hateful reviews to heart
reviews.content: While the Bratz movie is over the top and disgustingly cheesy, that's kind of the point. This movie was not made for people in their late teens and well into adulthood to try. When it first came out I took my little sisters and cousins to go see it and they loved it, which is the point. It is a movie made for children and young adolescents. As for the body issues; its a movie based on dolls. The average movie that takes place in a high school has thin, fit main characters. That can create issues but unlike those movies who had the option of choosing whoever they wanted for their main character and setting a tone, Bratz already had images their characters had to be based on. Getting made at them for sticking to the doll images is the same as getting angry at Barbie movies for not making thicker, more realistic cartoons.The lip-syncing was dramatic and not realistic but so what. Like previously stated, this was a children's movie and the majority of children do not notice or even care if they do notice. It was a cute movie with a nice, basic, child targeted message. Quite frankly I don't want to hear grown women talking about how horrible the movie was. I get stuck seeing children movies with the kids in my family all the time, and while I don't enjoy the movie and find them to be utterly ridiculous in a number of ways, I'm not going to write a review from my POV because i am not the audience target.The people who are attacking the dolls and saying they have a "promiscuous" image obviously don't understand the impact those dolls had, especially on colored girls. I used to play with those dolls because I loved that fact that they had big lips, I loved that their wardrobe included more than just sparkly tops, dresses, and ugly pink heels.

The worst of characters, the worst of plot, the worst of messages, the worst of stereotypes, the worst of song numbers, the worst of background music, the worst of writing, the worst of everything. This is by far one of the worst movies ever made.

This movie is truly a cinematic masterpiece. Anyone who says otherwise is wrong, grow up. From start to finish, this movie is impeccable, the filming, the acting, the soundtrack… (like come on, Bratitude has to be the greatest song ever made!!)  There is no movie which leaves me with such high levels of serotonin. I cannot fault these girls, or the writers! The incredibly racist stereotypes are so easy to ignore when the soundtrack is as good as it is! Please watch this movie, please give it 5 stars, you're delusional if you don't enjoy it. I'll have you know I studied a movie in my english class once so I KNOW what i'm talking about. I adore this movie, I need it injected in my veins

11/10 movie. the storyline does the franchise justice but keeps itself as a strong stand-alone product. i recommend this movie to all and i believe my life is better after watching this brilliant film. my outlook towards others and the world around me will never be the same and i believe without chloe, sasha, jade, and yasmin this would never be within reach or reason. thank you Sean McNamara for directing this movie into life. pls listen to bratitude on all streaming platforms. have a good day :D

I liked it! I thought it was a nice movie for young women and teens. Its a movie about friendship, staying true to yourself and being who you want to be. I really don't see the "dubious morals" noted in the overall critic formulation but that's critics for you. Has lots of corny lines and poor performances here and there but its still has lots of funny moments and good chemistry between Yasmin and her romance.

I remember watching some of this on TV back in 2008. While, as a movie based off of a toyline targeted towards girls, it was something of a foregone conclusion that this wasn't my thing, part of me tried to keep watching but it just came off as rather forgettable and bland. Many years later, I decide to cut corners by watching some caustic critics review it because I'd rather not be caught actually watching the film and dealing with some awkward questions and it seems I made the right call all those years ago. From its appearance, it appeared to be a truly shallow film with obnoxious humour, bad performances, questionable messages and a story that doesn't feel like it does a very good job encouraging its demographic to go buy Bratz dolls. One could argue that it actually brought out the worst in teen comedies (albeit a family-oriented one, rather than a pure PG-13 one). Transformers is the definitive victor here for best live-action film of 2007 based off of a toyline (and both had Jon Voight in them as well!).

I loved this movie growing up, and I love it now. For me it's like a feel good movie and definitely interesting enough to keep my attention. I love the message it gives. The outfits the girls wear aren't exactly as fashionable as I would have imagined for Bratz to wear. However, it's an all around wholesome movie and I will definitely continue watching it again and again.

This movie keeps the spirit of the Bratz franchise perfectly. The outfits are true to the style of the original dolls, and the personalities are too. True fans of the Bratz Universe will appreciate the dedication to detail and the expansion of the lore that this movie provides. Some of the scenes are stereotypical and disappointing (especially the depiction of Jade's mom), but overall this is a display of very healthy family/friend relationships. The focus is on friendship, not on boys or popularity. The characters are dynamic, and the mean girl is delightfully mean. The undertones are whimsically Marxist. The musical numbers are incredible, and the outfits are insane. If you want to think and learn, watch Schindler's List. If you want to eat cookie dough and laugh with your friends, watch Bratz.

As a past lover of the Bratz, when this film first came out, I was really excited to see it and see my favourite characters humanized. I had watched the TV show, the animated movies and played some of the video games so I hoped high. Granted, I was 15 when I first saw it and I did somewhat enjoy it, but since it was one of my favourite things still, I didn't mind the parts I was unsure of.

Watching it again now, though, I see the huge glaring problems. The acting by the majority of actors is pretty awful (example, Chloe in the shop admitting she doesn't have money for a new outfit). The story itself is dumbed down to your average teen high school movie but its morals are twisted and confusing. The music is pretty terrible. The worst part, personally, was that all of the fantastic parts of the Bratz, the interesting adventures, the morals that occasionally popped up to teach you about friendship and life, Burdine Maxwell and the Tweevils (who, in all honesty, could have been horrible or amazingly campy in a live action remake). Basically, everything larger than life and interesting about the Bratz was removed and replaced with flimsy, stereotypical backstories and personalities that are impossible to relate to or connect with in most senses.

For a child or a young teenager who likes Bratz, this is enjoyable. For anyone else, it's pretty awful.

I wanted this to be fun, smart and emotional and got neither. This should've been great.

If Bratz: The movie can be summed up in a word, it should Vain, or shallow, or better yet, insensitive. It shows all the teen movie clichés and stereotypes at their worst. It has no pure message other than "Girls are cool!". And the materialism is so bad, it feels like it's trolling the audience.
It must be left to tween girls and tween girls alone.

Offensive and stereotypical on virtually every level, Bratz is an exercise in patience, a High School Musical ripoff and a display that the main four protagonists are actually shallow, unappealing "heroes" (and I say so with a grain of salt).

Perfection takes time.

The Bratz arrive on the scene as freshmen in high school and an older established clique sees them as a threat and tries to break them up.  They work with different social classes to try and split the Bratz into new cliques putting their alliance at risk.  Can the girl's friendship withhold the assassination attempt on their popularity?

"You don't sound def."
"You don't look ignorant but don't judge a book, right?"

Sean McNamara, director of Soul Surfer, Raise Your Voice, Spare Parts, Race to Space, Hollywood Chaos, and 3 Ninjas: High Noon at Mega Mountain, delivers Bratz.  The storyline for this picture is below average and a huge downgrade from similar genre films like Mean Girls.  The acting is mediocre and a hair above made for television quality.

I wonder what it would be like to live day-by-day knowing you had participated in the creation of  the film adaptation of Bratz. You know, those dolls with the freakish lips and faces that dress with lower class than the "Me so horny!" Vietnamese hooker from Full Metal Jacket. Yes, those dolls.

One immediate question this film poses is, "How does one create a film based on a line of dolls that dress like Vegas strip hookers?" Or, there's also the questions, "Who the hell funded this film?" and "Who thought this was a wise investment?" There are many questions, with answers I don't think I'll ever get.

Going back to my first paragraph, I wonder what it must be like to be in director Sean McNamara's shoes. What could have possibly drawn this man to this project? Even taking into account his extensive directorial credits that include Disney Channel, Nickelodeon, and Cartoon Network episodes, what could possibly make anyone with such credits for directing programs for children want to take on a project that was destined to fail from the first pitch that there should be a film based on this particular brand of dolls?

I wonder if perhaps it was money being offered. But even so, what sort of monetary offering would be enough to entice anyone to direct something like this? Sure, you have the money, but you have the eternal shame in knowing that you helped birth one of the worst films ever made. But, this theory doesn't really hold water with me through even just a quick browsing of his work - specifically, his films.

A check of his filmography shows a strong leaning towards dramas, including ones with a faith angle and uplifting storylines, too. Though they received "meh" reviews from critics, his work with Soul Surfer and Spare Parts seem to be very well received by audiences. Hoovey seems to be decently received. He also directed a drama set during the Civil War which was met with mixed reviews called Field Of Lost Shoes, and even has a fantasy film coming out later this year called The Moon And The Sun which does sound a bit interesting, admittedly, considering its oddball premise. This to me, even though I have not seen his other work, shows signs of a much more ambitious director who has many ideas and lofty goals, complete with some solid fan followings for his works.

Plus, if his website's biography is to be believed, it raises more questions about why he directed this film. From this biography, I learned that the age of 12, during a trip to Ireland, his father bought him a super-8 camera. And as the plane taxied down the runway, he recorded it. This simple moment was apparently enough to inspire him to want to become a film-maker. I also wonder what else made him want to become a film-maker.

Every film-maker has their ambitions and inspirations, so what were his? Did he want to be the next great American (Maybe even international) director who would influence a new generation of film-makers and have film scholars talking for decades about his work? Did he want to create film classics? Or, was it perhaps something more modest, like being an indie director with creative freedoms and explorations into ideas mainstream films wouldn't allow for, complete with a small but dedicated fanbase? What were his inspirations? Classic American films? European or Asian art house films, perhaps? Or maybe, much like Quentin Tarantino, his inspirations are eclectic, obscure cult films? What were his goals? What were his inspirations?

I'm desperate to find out how and why. How did whatever goals, inspirations, or moments in life all lead to such a tragedy of film-making that had absolutely no hope of being remotely good? What went wrong? What led you to this point, Mr. McNamara? I don't think I've ever had a bad film confound me so much, and seen some major shit. But even with films that I hate more so than this one, they still had loftier goals and ideas that might have had some potential behind them. This is truly one of those rare cases where the idea was utterly hopeless. In fact, I haven't had a film make me ponder so much about its meanings since the Yasujiro Ozu masterpiece, Late Spring. Bratz is the antithesis to a film like Late Spring - it makes you ponder and contemplate for horrified and bewildered reasons, like trying to make sense of a tragic, senseless death.

The film focuses on 4 racially-stereotyped friends: Cloe, the bland blonde-haired white girl, Yasmin, the girl who's so Mexican there's a mariachi band in the house, her and her mother sing "La Cucaracha" at one point in the film, has an annoying brother with a thick Spanish accent, and there's also a Chevy Impala in their driveway (As if to remind you, "Hey, did you know that they're Mexicans?"), Jade, the smart Asian, and Sasha, the smart black girl whose parents are divorced.

The girls have been the best of friends ever since they were little and talk so much that they even skype one another. The girls are also obsessed with fashion and constantly discuss their outfits with one another. The girls are now getting ready to go to high school, where they assume that they'll all still be the best of friends.

But, as it turns out, that won't be the case, thanks to the principal's daughter, Meredith Baxter, who inexplicably has a dictatorial-style reign over the school and social cliques. Soon, the girls are split into different social cliques: Cloe joins the soccer team and immediately becomes only friends with the soccer team, Sasha becomes a cheerleader and only hangs out with other cheerleaders, Jade thanks to her stereotype, joins the science club and only hangs out with other members of the club, and Yasmin joins journalism, though she is most upset by this change events. It also turns out that Yasmin has singing talent, and with help from a deaf kid who is apparently a musical prodigy himself, she starts to grow in her talent. All the girls also meet attractive boys in their respective clubs.

2 years later in high school, and after being separated from one another, clumsy Yasmin inadvertently starts a food fight that results in all 4 girls being sent to detention after a statue of the principal is damaged during the food fight. After briefly hating one another for ending up in this situation, they become friends again, determined to end the cliques and get everyone to hang out together, resulting in a series of confrontations with the bitchy Meredith and planning a musical number for the upcoming talent show.

The storyline should have been a light, fluffy, albeit stupid bit of comedic fun. But even at the most basic levels, the story is completely doomed, which is made worse by how badly this film botches its messages about social cliques, self-esteem, and friendship. There is no reason to root for any of the characters as they are all soulless stereotypes which believe that through fashion and musical numbers, people will be brought together. No, Bratz. No they won't. The storyline makes me ponder the mental states of 3 - count 'em - 3 writers of this utter abortion, especially with all the stereotypes, poor messages, questionable role models, and complete lack of anything resembling a modicum of quality. The story is of such low quality that my brain felt like it was shutting down because of how the story will do absolutely nothing to engage it. You know how some people say that they would rather watch paint dry, and throw it around too often when discussing something they hate? Here, that would not be just throwing it around. Watching paint dry would literally be more stimulating than paying attention to this story.

I wonder how desperate an aspiring actor would have to be to agree to be in a film like this. Are you really so desperate to make a name for yourself in Hollywood that you would star in this film? You'd have less shame appearing in hardcore porn or bizarre fetish videos than you would starring in Bratz. Hell, I wouldn't be surprised if the cast was left with severe PTSD and found themselves locked in the padded room of an insane asylum for the rest of their lives after starring in this film. At a minimum, if I had starred in this film, I would have gone into hiding and never speak to anyone again out of shame.

The acting is horrible, but very difficult to properly describe. In fact, I will never be able to fully describe it to you. Well, to start off with the actresses, imagine the most irritating depictions of high school or college girls you've ever seen, or even just of prissy, fashion-obsessed girls you've ever seen in films. Now take those irritations you've felt and multiply them at least one hundred fold. Those are the performances given by the actresses in this film. They give performances that are bad beyond any earthly word. I don't even know if the darkest depths of Hell have a proper word for this sort of bad acting.

The other cast members are hardly any better, and continuing his downward spiral, Jon Voight appears in this film as the principal, and seems to have given up any semblance of respect he once had for acting. He gives one of the most hollow, soulless, dead-behind-the-eyes performances I've ever seen in films.

The acting is bad past the point of extraordinary, and crosses into the realm of legendary. You won't believe it, and you can't describe it to others. It is something that must be witnessed, but that would be too cruel a task to do.

There is no entertainment. There is literally nothing of redeeming value to be found. There's hardly a story, there are no likable or living characters, there is no funny humor, every song and dance number is excruciating (And this is coming from someone who gave Xanadu 5/5 stars and Grease 2 4/5 stars), the messages negate themselves, and it's overall an annoying, boring, and soul-sucking experience to endure. Have you ever known what it's felt like to watch a film so bad that it feels like it's sucking out the will to live? That's what Bratz will do to you, I shit you not. I hated the characters and hoped that they would all die, so the film would end faster, or perhaps that I would die and the agony would be over.

Though I would talk about the humor in a longer paragraph, I'm not going to. It is unspeakably bad.

Shortly before he died, Roger Ebert released his final list of the 10 best films he had ever seen. One of them was Citizen Kane. In the brief section about Citizen Kane, he talked about he and other film scholars spent several hours studying every single frame of that film. EVERY FRAME. I would never do that, no matter how much I loved a film. But it wouldn't take that kind of examination to tell you that every single frame of Bratz is a complete failure. Just pause the film at any point and try to find something of value in that still frame. You can't. There is nothing.

Bratz has now cemented itself as being not only one of the 10 worst comedies, musicals, chick flicks, and family films, it has now gone down as one of the 10 all-time worst films I have ever seen, period. Save your sanity. Save your soul. Save yourself. Once you watch Bratz, you will not come out of it the same person you were before. It is a life-changing, unforgettable bad film that will haunt me for the rest of my days, as I forever try to figure out how something so horrible and misconceived was ever allowed to exist or be pitched to studios in the first place. It is one of the ultimate tragedies of bad film-making. A film so heinous, it could be reclassified as a war crime or at least, an inhumane form of torture by the Geneva Convention.

rt_summary: Yasmin (Nathalia Ramos), Jade (Janel Parrish), Sasha (Logan Browning) and Cloe (Skyler Shaye) are best friends and fashion mavens. The well-dressed quartet faces unexpected challenges to a lifelong bond when each one enters Carry Nation High, where senior Meredith Baxter Dimly (Chelsea Staub) rules the school's social cliques with an iron fist. As peer pressure threatens to divide the girls, they must learn how to band together and how to achieve true empowerment.
